reviewText:
Cinders is a pretty fantastic visual novel, full of strong female characters and decisions that have consequences. It's a darker, more mature take on the classic Cinderella fairy tale, but with some clever twists. The artwork and music are really gorgeous and add a lot to the story. It's also worth noting that this is one of the rare visual novels that uses an art style other than anime.

The game's a bit short and even going back and playing several endings won't take much longer than a few hours. Unfortunately, there isn't a lot of replay value. While there are a lot of different endings in the game, things become a little tedious after you've played through a couple of times. Other than achievement hunting, there's not much payoff for getting all the endings.

Even though it's brief, the story and characters are engaging and it's an enjoyable experience while it lasts. It's also a visual novel that's a bit heavier on the novel part than straight-up dating sims; several different pairings can occur, but the focus isn't entirely on romance.

I personally think that the $20 price tag is a little steep for such a short game though, so look for sales or bundle deals.

reviewText:
I'm really interested in visual novels, particularly ones aimed at women, so I've been trying to make a point of everything available in English. I have to say, this is probably the best one I've seen so far.

The aesthetics of this game are amazing. The art is beautiful, as you can see from the screenshots, but something they don't show is how everything looks in movement. The backgrounds are subtly animated and the text appears on the screen in a magical shine of color. It's mostly small touches, but it makes the game feel very unique from a lot of other indie visual novels that originally came out in English.

Another thing that makes Cinders really stand out is the way they show you how your choices are affecting the game. Every time a line is changed due to one of your choices, a chime plays and a symbol appears in the corner. Once you reach certain goals (which you gain achievements for on Steam) the starting menu will change to show your awards. And after you reach an ending, there's a screen that shows you all the possible variables in the ending you achieved. I'm impressed to see that it looks like there's a LOT of variables in the ending I got, which makes me really interested in what other possibilities there are! (It should also help the game have lots of value as well--my first playthrough was probably around three hours or so, so I'm expecting to get a good amount of playtime in to complete all the endings and branching paths...10-15 hours is what I'm estimating right now.)

I was also impressed by the number of choices present in the game--they happen frequently, and never feel pointlessly shoved in. I don't know how well the illusion of choice will hold up in further playthroughs but at least in this first one I really felt like my choices had an impact, which makes me very pleased.

As for the story--I loved it. Nearly all of the characters are interesting and have different layers to uncover from what I've seen in the game so far. I particularly like what's been done with the stepsisters--the game doesn't quite make excuses for them, but does a lot to make it make sense why they'd be so cruel to Cinders. Finding out more about Sophia in particular (who is probably my favorite character) is something I'm looking forward to trying to uncover in later playthroughs.

If I had one complaint, the only thing I could come up with is that at times the game's dialogue clashes with the tone they seem to be going for. They're trying to make the story feel like it's in a historical place--one where there are elements of fantasy, but that could otherwise reasonably exist at some point in history. But a lot of the dialogue feels oddly modern and even occasionally slang-y. I don't think this is exactly a problem, but it does clash at times with their attempts to make things feel 'historical.'

But honestly, that's a nitpick, and one I gave partially so this review wouldn't be completely glowing. Otherwise, this is probably the best Visual Novel I've played, hands down. I'm glad it's finally showed up on Steam.

There’s many things that I like about this game so I’ll do a list:

>>>GENERAL STUFF:
-The art gorgeous. There are even small background animations as well which makes the scenes livelier. I’m so in love with the art is almost hurts!

-If we make a decision and it affects the story differently, a flower appears on the top right of the screen. It’s kind of like the Walking Dead’s “____ will remember that”. Personally, I like the instant feedback on my decisions.

-The dialouge between characters can feel a little stiff and awkward at times. Maybe it's because the characters aren't that close with each other and that's why it gives off that vibe.

-I love how when we get achievements, the title screen updates and things are added as we discover more things. What in the jellybeans, that’s AMAZING!

-The music is gorgeous. There are times when I stop and listen and go “whoa!” one of the conversations got pretty tense and the music followed suit.

-I like the attention to detail when the words roll onto the screen. It is as if each word was cast into existence by a small fairy as little colourful sparks burst behind every appearing word.

We know when a person is speaking hurriedly, maybe even angrily since the text appears very quickly. When words are spoken by characters with emphasis, the text emerges slowly, and there are pauses at key moments to create tension. I’m usually the type of person who clicks twice to see all the text appear all at once since I’m an impatient reader, but Cinders has made me stop and enjoy watching the text tap happily along the screen.



>>>STORY:
-The story has a lot of variations (player choices and endings). One ending may have small, but still significant changes that shows up in the epilogue depending on the choices we made.

-There is a convenient skip option as well so there isn’t a big pain when replaying for different possibilities.

-I personally loved bonding with Cinder’s sisters. I love them and easily got attached to them, problems, flaws and all. If we bond with them a certain way, they react differently to us, differently to others, and maybe even towards themselves.


>>>OVERALL:
It’s a great game, with a great story, amazing music, stunning art, and the list goes on! It allows us to make choices as we read making us more invested. There are many paths and endings to discover.

You may not be too into it if you’re not a big reading fan. But if you enjoy reading or visual novels, Cinders is a MUST GET! Even if you aren’t into visual novels, give this one a go, maybe your tastes will change! There is a demo on their main site to try out at MoaCube.

With some regret, I have to say that I do not recommend this game.

I really wanted to like this game; the premise was promising and the art style is beautiful (though the scenes are limited; don't expect much variety).

This visual novel has the makings of a great novel--great artwork, interesting characters, a wealth of different options, the ability to skip scenes easily on a second playthrough (viewing only the new content you haven't seen before), and most importantly to me, your choices change the outcome of your story. Every choice matters.

The only real fault I had with this game was the atrocious writing. It was painful--unrealistic language, blatant foreshadowing, laughable and sometimes downright confusing conversations. The makers of this game went so far into making sure that the player was aware of the nuances of each character that they beat you over the head with them, and then beat the horse you rode in on too. I like subtle, complex characterization, and character growth should be something developed over time and with a touch more realism. Rather than creating nuanced dialogue the game screams it at you, and then has the main character repeat it to herself in her alone time just to make sure you didn't misunderstand anything.

I paid $4 for this game via Humble Bundle , and spend roughly 3 hours doing two playthroughs (with numerous bouts of getting up for pizza and tea). If I had paid $20 via steam, I suspect my review would be that much more vitriolic...if you go to the effort of making a well-crafted game, you should spend some time crafting the text with the same dexterity shown elsewhere.

reviewText:
It's rather unusual to see a visual novel coming from somewhere other than Japan that doesn't attempt to merely emulate those that do, but instead takes hold of the genre and carves a unique path for itself that shows VNs have a lot more to offer than we've thus seen. In the case of Cinders, it also manages to update a classic fairytail into a far more mature and modern story, turning Cinderella into a newly captivating adventurer that eschews many of the originals childish elements for mystery and intrigue. It stumbles a bit along the way, as if walking in its own pair of undersized glass slippers, but on the whole amounts to something unexpectedly enthralling and maybe just a bit magical.

I can't imagine anyone is unfamiliar with the story of Cinderella, so I'll skip the introductions. The vile mother and sisters, sad girl living as a servant waiting for the world to change, glass slippers and prince charming are all here as you'd expect, but where Cinders differs is in taking a simple fairy tail and turning it into a mature and intriguing story that is wildly different than how you remember it. Character interactions are full of personal dialogue and emotion, turning the original cliches into actual people you can relate and empathize with. Cinders sisters might be cold, but once their reasons are explained it's hard not to feel sorry for them despite their cruelties. The prince may appear to live a life of carefree amusement, but on the inside his constant questioning of his actions is tearing him apart and making him question his own motives. There are certainly moments when it becomes overly self indulgent with some of its writing, and a few endings feel a bit hollow (though that's to be expected with how many there are), but these moments are overshadowed by the majority of the dialog, which is hugely engrossing and when compiled with the element of your own choices becomes even more compelling, as you shape the outcome to any number of different paths.

Which brings me to one of the few areas Cinders slips up a bit, at least in the view of someone who wishes to see more than the one ending they arrive at. Throughout the story (which should take you around 2-5 hours depending on your reading speed) you encounter a myriad of choices which change the story and eventually decide your characters fate. The issue arises in the sheer number of decisions that can have an impact on the ending, and the very limited number of saves you are given, which means you are required to skip through huge amounts of text again and again as you reload and make minor alterations to your choices in the attempts to see a new ending. It all becomes greatly repetitive and takes far more time than it otherwise might had you been given more freedom in the number of saves you have, as well as making it quicker to skip through dialog you've already read before.

But ultimately it's a somewhat inconsequential complaint as for those not obsessed with seeing every ending, the first run through the story isn't the least bit affected and just as captivating as ever. Least I forget Cinders is also remarkably pretty to look at, with fantastic art and a ton of minor details bringing the picture to life, from background objects to character expressions. It's a bold new direction for visual novels, a genre that's been stagnant and underrepresented outside of Japan for a long time, and a brilliant first attempt by developer MoaCube which I hope is but the first of many more to come.

reviewText:
Cinders is a colorful, emotionally-vibrant Visual Novel, starring Cinders, a wide-eyed, fiery-red, female protagonist. Cinders is about to embark on a journey—a journey of choices. The story will most certainly bring to memory another classical tale of romance, intrigue, betrayal & the pursuit of happiness.

Choices are the core gameplay element in Cinders. The choices you make really do matter. The world will unfold around you according to the decisions you make—and you will always be aware of how they affect what occurs next. The gameplay mechanic for this is that a budding branch will emerge from the corner of the screen to denote an event playing out that has been mitigated by previous decisions. This conspires to make a living world, where you’re not an observer but a participant.

While choices are at the core of Cinders, they dance around the diverse characters. The characters are complex, disturbed, scarred, & much more. None of the characters are simply good or bad. They reach out and play with your emotions as if they were flesh & blood.

The artwork in Cinders is colorful & vibrant. You’ll oftentimes find yourself looking at the background scenery, to catch a look at the swaying shrubbery, or the flickering fire. The soundtrack is diverse & emotionally fitting to each scene as it unfolds. It’s easy to get lost in the simple background melodies.

Cinders has a full screen option, with the option to choose screen ratio. The game looked great on a 30” screen at a 16:10 ratio playing in full screen mode.

In conclusion, Cinders is loosely based on one of the classics, & most certainly worth a look if you’re interested in the Visual Novel genre. It will make your heart tingle & your nerves race as you take an emotional journey with Cinders.

reviewText:
Although it is a retelling of the classic fairytale Cinderella, the new approach makes it seem like another story altogether.

Genre: Fantasy/Adventure
Duration: 2 to 3 hours for one ending; 10 to 15 hours for all endings.
Developed by: MoaCube, 2012

By playing as the namesake protagonist, you are introduced to a fantasy world in which you must deal with your stepmother and stepsisters at first, later meeting nobility, fairies, salesmen and townsfolk. You do so through choices and map movement intermissions in the narrative. So as not to leave you confused, the game flashes a wooden branch icon on the upper right corner of the screen everytime a previous choice is showing its consequence.

Cinders is structured so as to give your choices an aspect of freedom: there are not correct choices and you will always reach a satisfying ending that reflects your behaviour throughout the story. This means one single playthrough will last for about two hours, but one ending is just a glimpse of the stories Cinders has to offer.

The greatest strength this visual novel has is probably its characters: no character is completely redeemed nor degraded. They are complex, round characters with motivations and goals that you can relate yourself to, enhancing the moral aspect of the choices: each and every character has a lot to be explored, making for a consistent world with strong characters - and many strong female characters - and a sense that you are free to make your own judgement.

This groundedness, however, doesn't stop the game from sporting a most pleasant fairytale atmosphere. The art and the music, through coherent design and stylistic choices, gives Cinders a fine identity and a unique feel down to minute details, such as small animations on the background and on the sprites. As such, it's easy to get used to the art style even if it's not commonly used in visual novels. Such attention to identity helps in the establshment of an emotional link between you and Cinders' world.

If only fow how bold it is, Cinders is a must for anyone who appreciates story-driven experiences with complex characters and a lot of room for the player to decide what happens next.

Positive:

*Great fairytale impression
*Many choices and many endings
*Fleshed out characters
*Music is comfortable to listen to and the sound design is adequate
*Consistent art and world

Negative:

*Short playthroughs. You might not feel the need to see other endings/epilogues
*Though the game shows when a choice is reflected on the progress of the story, some choices are still lost in perspective
*It's expensive

I originally had this game on my wishlist based on the art style alone. Turns out, it's a re-imagining of the tale of Cinderella. And it is a visual novel, where your choices have an actual impact on the story.

Graphics / art - 5/10
Let me get this out of the way since this is what first pulled me in. Mmmm ... not that impressive at the end of the day. Most of the characters look a little weird, and there's just not much animation. I know it's a visual novel, but it feels like they could have done a little more. So it's not bad, just not quite up to its potential in this area.

Story / characters - 8/10
The story itself is slightly adapted, and I have to say the developers did a great job. The wicked stepmother and the two evil stepsisters are actual characters with personalities, and through the story you can understand some of the reasons why they behave as they do. Truly a tremendous spin on a stale old tale.

The developers also get into why there is a ball, which is pretty interesting.

The most annoying character is probably Cinders herself. In some ways she behaves like any normal person in a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ situation would. However, other times she's a bit whiny and preachy.

My favorite character was actually the stepmother. She's less of a demon when you get to know her reasoning and motivations. And her drive is impressive.

The side characters beyond the main ones (Cinders and her step-family being the core characters), are less interesting, and it seems like there are some interesting mysteries into their backgrounds that unfortunately don't get fleshed out. Like what the relationship is between Cinder's mother and some of the other side characters. What happened to Cinder's mother?

Gameplay - 10/10
As with most visual novels, it's mostly reading. However, at key points you get to make decisions. I wish I had read about the game before playing to better appreciate the impact of decisions. It would have let me know how important it is to use all of your (I think) 10 save slots so that you don't have to restart the story from the beginning to find all the endings.

Basically, you can be good, neutral or evil based on your decisions. And your decisions impact your route to the ball, which suitor you end up with, and whether you're even happy at the end. I overwrote a lot of my old saves as I went along, so I was really limited in my endings. However, I think there are a total of about 12 variations.

Pretty incredible, eh? The game itself isn't amazing, but when you realize how the developers freshened up the source material, you can't help but be impressed!

8/10

reviewText:
Amazing game, and I say that as someone who doesn't normally play visual novels because: a) they are usually drawn in the style of anime, and b) they are usually dating sims -- I find neither of those two things particularly appealing. This game, however, is not even close to being a dating sim (although there are different romance options you can choose to pursue) and the art style is miles away from anime and very beautiful.

The story is a retelling of the Cinderella fairytale with a lot more depth, featuring well-rounded characters, complicated familial relations and meaningful choices. It emphasizes the extent to which characters' personal choices are limited by/the product of their circumstances and surroundings. The wicked stepmother and stepsisters are not simple archetypal chracters but complex figures with motivations and agendas that arise from their life circumstances. The main character Cinders, the young woman who lives as a servant in her own house, is trying to take destiny in her own hands and break free from her current circumstances, but cannot do so without outside help. The game makes a point: despite her desire to be independent and have agency, her available options are nevertheless to some extent the product of particular conditions that are outside of her influence (of her father marrying as he did, of her mother ensuring Cinders gets help when she needs it, etc).

The writting is very good and the choices in the game are meaningful; I found replaying the game to explore different results very interesting. The first playthrough takes about 3 hours, while subsequent playthroughs can be made a lot shorter as there's an option to skip through dialogues that you've read in previous playthroughs.

Definitely recommended for people who love good stories and don't mind reading a bunch.

It has enough different choices to provide for some different outcomes or at least tweaks/versions of the handful of coded outcomes; the storyline is overall romance driven.
Situations and consequences end up lacking some shades of grey, but then, which choice based game is not a bit black and white? Whether you like fairy tales that blossom in royal weddings, hopeless romances that overcome social judgement and class differences, arranged marriages brewed in cynical logics and fueled by a drive for advancement, you are likely to find a natural flow of answers that fit your virtual inclination.
There is replayability to satisfy curiosity, though it comes encumbered by some medium lengths carved in stone events and dialogues, so that will eventually dry out.
For the time curiosity lasts, a very enjoyable chose your path game, well worth a first try and a couple more run throughs.

So why play this game?: you d like to see the face of the cinderella in you who does not speak her name.

reviewText:
A visual novel based on the story Cinderella.
This game really presents itself well; it's probably the most polished visual novel I've played, with the only real issue being a typo I found. Simple things like the effect of text appearing on the screen look really great.
The art style is colorful, beautiful, and detailed. There's some animation effects on the backgrounds which adds a lot more to the feel of the game than you'd expect. Just small things like water of a lake shimmering, fire moving, sunrays, and things like that. The only character animations are really facial expressions, and sometimes they'll shift poses, but that's more of a rare thing... though the characters will change outfits or poses for different scenes.
The music is really well done and there's a good variety here, but nothing I really focused on much.

There are 4 endings, but multiple variations of those endings based on how you treated certain characters and things like that. So there's some replayability here, but the story still plays out mostly the same, with just some extra scenes and dialogue peppered in based on some choices you make. A lot of times I felt like the banter back and forth may not add a whole lot to the story, and doesn't create that much extra character depth... ultimately leading to longish periods of time between choice branches. This could also limit replayability, but there is a button to fast-forward through the dialogue that will still pause when there's a choice to be made, or when you reach a new scene you haven't seen before. A really awesome feature. Even though you can skip through quickly using this method, it still takes a LONG time to fast-forward through everything. The story is kind of that long... I think when I started a new story to get a different ending, it still took me an hour to play through even though I fast-forwarded through the majority of the story.

The choices in this game can affect a lot, I think. Even though the majority of scenes STILL happen no matter what, the differences in the story with how the characters treat you (and even how your character treats them) provides a more personal feel... rather than picking options that feel out-of-place of your character, your character changes with your options. It's pretty nice in this way.

Another really awesome detail this game provides is when you unlock achievements (which relate to the story and in-game decisions.) With each one you unlock, a change happens to the main menu screen... most of the time an item gets added to the scene. It's really a nice detail and just goes to show how much attention was put into this game. There's also a reward" menu where you can see all the unique things you've unlocked

reviewText:
Basic Premise: Shape Cinderella’s character, attitude, and reactions to her upbringing and choose how she escapes. The many character trait and action choices that actually impact the story’s end make this visual novel stand out. I’ve played through it several times and still have not found all the paths.

Music: Most visual novels’ and sims’ soundtracks have me hunting for the mute button, but this one is gorgeous.

Visuals: Gracjana Zielinska’s art has a detailed, ethereal quality without becoming prissy or cutesy.  It’s beautiful.  I’m so pleased she’s returning for Solstice.

Programming: I appreciate the ability to quickly skip through already viewed scenes with one button press.  All visual novels should implement this.

Writing: *thunk**thunk* *thunk*  That noise, dear friend, is the characters’ dialog and the insights into their behavior being delivered with all the subtlety of a frying pan to the back of the skull. The reader is never left to infer anything. Cinders’ inner monologue or other characters will spell it out. During the first long conversation between Cinders and Sophia, they tell their back-story and motivations to one another without the reservation and self-protection that the back-story would naturally have bred.  It drove me crazy until I remembered Dostoevsky’s The Brothers Karamazov. Yes, the two works don’t seem to have much in common but bear with me. Like Karazmov, Cinders uses characters to represent a consistent type of person rather than how you and I would interact on a day-to-day basis. Once you go with it, they both deliver a good story and observations on human nature.  Boom. A 2012 visual novel saved by Dostoevsky.

Writing: The banter between characters usually makes me smirk (Sophia and Gloria should have their own spin-off). The only exception is the romantic dialog. Excuse me for a moment, game, while I fetch some nachos to go with all this cheese. Fortunately, the game has many endings with no romance whatsoever.

Writing: The grammar, spelling, and word choice are nearly perfect. Kudos to the editor.

Female Characters: The writers clearly spent more of their effort developing the women. Cinders, Carmosa, Gloria, Sophia, and Madame Ghede all have distinct personalities and goals. Sophia’s snark is always welcome: “The only things missing from this picture is holding hands and singing. And dancing. Possibly in circles. In the middle of a flowery meadow. I think I might throw up.” I want an ending in which she and Cinders escape together.

Male Characters: The men aren’t bad, but they lack the depth and care the women received. I won’t dwell on them (particularly since the developer has already addressed this), but here’s a brief run-down.  Tobias is a childhood friend who tends to deliver motivation speaker advice with the aforementioned frying pan; I want to like you, Toby, but you have to stop thwacking me over the head.  Perrault is a guard captain caught between duty and ethics; he is my favorite of the three.  Prince Basile is he least developed of the three, though the conversations between him and Perrault are good. He and Cinders discuss Levia Malich’s work in a scene ripped straight from Ever After, but other than that I enjoy their interactions.

Bottom Line: I recommend this to anyone (not just women) who wants a strong, competent protagonist and enjoys tinkering to discover different endings. If you happen to have a snarky sense of humor, even better.

reviewText: I bought this game on Humble Bundle since it came with a bunch of visually pleasing looking games. Out of sheer curiosity I tried this one because I loved the artwork and figured I could use a change of pace and just play this Visual Novel on nights I just want to relax. Who would've thought I would enjoy this game so much! Which is strange because it is incredibly repetitive since it is just a story, but I love just unlocking all the endings and seeing all the variations within the game. My sis and I have played this for hours now and we haven't tired of it yet. Incredibly unexpected from a Visual Novel, but definitely a pleasant surprise.  If you're looking for something casual and fun to play as you relax, I definitely recommend this game. My only big issue with this is that the dialogue can feel really preachy and didactic, to the point it gets a little pretentious. Certain characters aren't as fleshed out as others (i.e. The Prince, The Fairy, etc.), and then I feel the dev really pushes you to like and respect certain characters when in reality they're still quite awful no matter what choices you make in the game. But all in all, there are plenty of dialogue gems within this game that out weight the cons, and I've been hooked since day one.

reviewText:
Best Visual Novel I've played to completion on Steam, bar none.

Its art and presentation are gorgeous, with subtle movements doing much to break up the static nature of a VN. The writing is smart, witty and clever and the characters themselves compliment the themes of the story with aplomb. The game is somewhat insistent with its themes, but they're pretty good things to hear and I think anyone can gain something or learn something about themselves from reading this.

It hits all the high notes. The characters are nuanced and complicated and the decisions you make really do make an impact; the game even has a nice feature that notifies you when changes to the plot and dialogue is happening. It's just an exceptionally well-built VN that does an admirable job at deconstructing and toying with fairy tale tropes. I recommend it immensely.

I can say this game was a  treat to play. It takes the story of Cinderella and puts more control for Cinderella's character (in this case Cinders) to make her own way. There is some discussion on whether the game really promotes independence, as a lot of the independence options are tracked as evil or morally questionable. This is a legit complaint, but I question if it's to fit the time period rather than our own sense of values.

Anywho, good game.

reviewText:
Been a while since I played an interactive novel for 3 straight hours. And it's worth it.
The writing is witty and interesting, the choices always give you a moments pause because oh, that one seems like a good idea while that other one will get me where I'm aiming while that third one screams horrid fun.

I like that each complete playthrough adds to the title screen (oh, and achievements obviously but who collects them these days?) which gives me a sense of fulfillment after each playthrough.
And thank the Gods for the skip function or those 3hrs would have been much longer and really all I wanted was Perrault (Still didn't get the ending I wanted but I know where I went wrong and oh gods why did I only save once?)

But yes, multiple endings, each with a little 'and so the story ends' because if there's one thing I appreciate (other than skip functions and swordsmen with way too many belts) it's finding out what happens to the story AFTER I've clicked my way through it amidst giggles.

My one annoyance is the ball scene. The next line is kind of a spoiler, I guess?
Regardless of the choices you make, it doesn't change because Cinders will still dance with His Lordship, who'll flirt and she'll smirk and coo 'tell me more darling' while I sit here wondering if she's forgotten her dear Captain's poetry already.
Maybe if I make more drastic choices it'll change, but I doubt it.

That said, that's honestly an incredibly minor detail (because skip function. I may mention this a lot but have you ever played an interactive novel without one? Don't.) and as above, the writing and endings definitly calls for replays.
Plus I kinda wanna see if I can get the girls on good terms because ho boy would that be an awesome ending (please be an awesome ending)

This is definitly a game I'd recommend to those that enjoy a good story, witty text and a pretty art style.
It's Cinderella, but with more spunk, a good dose of sass and less frolicking vermin.
I should have started with that.

Now if you'll excuse me, I need to go laugh about a well-respected guardsman making odd animal noises in the bushes.

reviewText:
The unfortunate flaw of this game is that even if someone goes for every achievement and story outcome, the average amount of time to accomplish this is around 15-20 hours, depending on whether you get help from walkthroughs or not. I think most people can agree that more gameplay time is preferable. However, I'd like to say that this is the ONLY flaw of this game (obviously, that's just my opinion though).

If you like visual novels, I highly recommend this one. Every single choice affects the ending of the story. There are also about a dozen different story ending combinations to be made. As the description of the game states, it is an adult version of the Cinderella story. However, Cinders (her name in this version) doesn't have to be the traditional character she's known to be. She can be villainous, independent, strong-willed, ambitious, etc. She can have whatever type of personality you want her to have. The best part is that she doesn't have to go after the prince. She can plot revenge against her stepmother and stepsisters, unlike the traditional character. She can be absolutely defiant and rebellious, also unlike the traditional character. But let's say you want her to be a nice, good person, but still establish her independence (from the Prince and her stepfamily), you can do that combination as well! Point being, this doesn't have to be the typical Cinderella story unless you want it to be. The story and the character are what you make it and for a visual novel, that's the best a gamer can ask for.

Other good things about the game:
- The artwork is beautiful (and sort of gothic).
- The music is well-done and fitting to the atmosphere of the game.
- There are other suitors Cinders can go for other than the Prince.
- The gamer can see the point of view/character development of the stepsisters/stepmother if they wish to (making them more human than the original story).
- The game truly causes the gamer to put thought into the choices they make.

I'll say it again: if you like visual novels, I HIGHLY recommend this game.

reviewText:
Now, this is a fantastic game. What really stood out for me was the stunning art. The visuals are very well-done and they really help set the tone for Cinders. The characters felt alive; they're not shallow like the ones in the fairy tale. A lot of thought had definitely been put into the dialogues as they're engaging and witty at times. They really speak to the characters. The storyline follows the generic one of the Cinderella, with many interesting variations thrown in to make Cinders stand on its own and speak to the players.

There are four endings to the game, with some variations which are shaped by your decisions. In theory, Cinders has very high replayability due to the sheer number of choices and branches that it has. However, I lost interest before discovering all the ending variations. For one, I found the variations to be minor. Two, it was tedious to have to go through the same events and dialogues over and over again, even in fast-forward. After a certain point, it was just not worth the effort to go through the motions to see how else the conclusions could vary, especially since I was quite satisfied with the ones I did get already.

I think a contributing factor to my eventual lost of interest is that I feel the choices I made reflected my values and overall outlook. You could find that some decisions really speak to you and there's just no desire to choose the alternatives; it's likely that you'll like the first ending you got the most. And that's the case for me.

reviewText:
I picked up this game after never having had much of an interest in interactive novels, and can say that this game is very easy to pick up for those new to the genre. Having not played or researched many games of the genre, I can't really comment on how innovative this is within the context of its genre. I was thinking of postponing a review of Cinders until after I had played more of the genre, but I doubt I will do this in the near future. So here is a review, to be returned to if I do ever have something to add.

A pretty great interactive take on a classic tale, the large amount of well thought-out endings based on choices made through the game lend well to the feeling of coming of age of the heroine, Cinders. It is also a refreshing take to give Cinderella more agency and control over her life, though she as a character may not realise how much influence she has. The endings closest to the original fairytale really felt well-earned as you really felt like you had to push Cinders to making responsible decisions despite the temptation to let Cinders be snarky and dwell on revenge.

All-in-all the decisions felt quite organic in how they impacted the story despite the fixed events throughout the story and the number of game-influencing variables which is remarkable in any game. I thoroughly enjoyed replaying to find all the endings and the variants therein, and the eight save slots, fast-forward function and the flower indicator for branching story moments were a great help in this. It would have been nice to have an even faster way of scrolling or even skipping to the next decision, but what was there worked well.

The music was great and perfectly suited to the mood of the game, and so were the beautiful painted-looking environments.  The touch of movement and change in lighting was also well done, present but subtle. The character design is very solidly well done, such that the few trappings of anime and manga in the style are not off-putting even to those who they do not appeal to.

It is great to see this smart and well-made interactive retelling of Cinderella come to Steam where sales will hopefully help it reach a much greater audience.

I picked up this game after never having had much of an interest in interactive novels, and can say that this game is very easy to pick up for those new to the genre. Having not played or researched many games of the genre, I can't really comment on how innovative this is within the context of its genre. I was thinking of postponing a review of Cinders until after I had played more of the genre, but I doubt I will do this in the near future. So here is a review, to be returned to if I do ever have something to add.

A pretty great interactive take on a classic tale, the large amount of well thought-out endings based on choices made through the game lend well to the feeling of coming of age of the heroine, Cinders. It is also a refreshing take to give Cinderella more agency and control over her life, though she as a character may not realise how much influence she has. The endings closest to the original fairytale really felt well-earned as you really felt like you had to push Cinders to making responsible decisions despite the temptation to let Cinders be snarky and dwell on revenge.

All-in-all the decisions felt quite organic in how they impacted the story despite the fixed events throughout the story and the number of game-influencing variables which is remarkable in any game. I thoroughly enjoyed replaying to find all the endings and the variants therein, and the eight save slots, fast-forward function and the flower indicator for branching story moments were a great help in this. It would have been nice to have an even faster way of scrolling or even skipping to the next decision, but what was there worked well.

The music was great and perfectly suited to the mood of the game, and so were the beautiful painted-looking environments.  The touch of movement and change in lighting was also well done, present but subtle. The character design is very solidly well done, such that the few trappings of anime and manga in the style are not off-putting even to those who they do not appeal to.

It is great to see this smart and well-made interactive retelling of Cinderella come to Steam where sales will hopefully help it reach a much greater audience.

reviewText:
Cinders is definitely a departure from what you normally find on Steam. A stunning and interesting adaptation of Cinderella, Cinders is a visual novel and Choose Your Own Adventure story that captures, in a grown-up way, the spirit you had and the magic you felt reading as a child. The only two things creating this world are artwork and music, as the dialogue – the heart of the game – is all text. Surprisingly, I did not come across many grammatical errors, and being the English major I am, I was certainly looking. Editors have done quite the job. The storytelling was thoughtful and well-crafted; the writing was intelligent and contained more adult humour than I expected. In the short period of time it took to get through the first playthrough (roughly five hours), the writing delved into the pasts of a few characters and built them up to be more than just one-dimensional.

Though most of the art is static, the odd flicker of the fireplace, shimmer of water or subtle eye and lip movements somehow bring it entirely to life. Though more colourful and detailed, the artwork does remind me of that which you would find in old hardcover fairytale books. The ambient music is absolutely beautiful and changes with each scene, though because it was the only auditory element it did have me longing for even more variety at times (as the songs are repeated); I wish the soundtrack contained even more.

Though based on a traditional story with a subdued and passive female protagonist, this modern adaptation takes some unexpected and satisfying departures and shines more light on the complex relationships between the characters and Cinders’ struggle for independence and thirst for freedom. There is a focus on family and the conflicts between taking care of others and taking care of oneself. The heart of the story is finding one’s own path in life and understanding that each choice you make has a consequence, either immediately or in the future, for both yourself and those around you. In this way, the replay value of this game is pretty spectacular: it has four possible endings. And in all honesty, I think I am actually going to play through to see all of them.

If you enjoy reading and visual novels, Cinders is absolutely with a playthrough (or four!).

reviewText:
+Lots of choices
+Well-written dialogue
+Beautiful artwork

-Controls seem a little off
-Girly theme might not appeal to all

Overall score: 8/10

To begin, let me start off by saying that Cinderella is my least favorite fairy tale princess. Why? Because Cinderella cries and her Fairy Godmother magically fixes everything for her. Seriously? A crybaby princess? I think I’d prefer narcoleptic Sleeping Beauty over that.

Thankfully, Cinders is not that story.

Instead, Cinders is a game where you need to decipher the motivations and secrets of the people around you. You want a Fairy Godmother? Of course you can have one! You just have to work for it. You have to use logic to figure out what the best choices are, and, unlike some other VNs, the choices you have to make actually do make sense when you think about it. There are also many choices to make (I counted 47 on my first playthrough), so the game has plenty of re-playability if you want to get every ending. In addition, I found the artwork to be beautiful (or at least charming) and the dialogue was very believable (and funny at times).

The two critiques I have of this game were easily overlooked by me, but I figured they were worth mentioning. First, the buttons are a little off. Intuitively, you would think that you would hover over the words for each button in order to make your choice. However, you actually have to be about half a centimeter above the buttons in order to click things. It’s not a deal-breaker, but it’s slightly annoying. Second, you’re playing as Cinders. Therefore, the game has an obviously girly theme. Even as a girl, I always thought that fairy tale princesses were too girly, and I never cared for them that much. I can imagine that, as a guy, this game might be a bit much. However, I would like to say that you can definitely still enjoy Cinders if you’re a masculine guy, as long as you’re an avid fan of VNs. If you think it’s still too girly, wait until Moa Cube releases Solstice.

Overall, Cinders is a very good VN and if you’re fan of the genre, you should definitely give this one a go.

reviewText:
A very nice surprise and my favorite from the Humble Eye Candy Bundle, and eye candy it is, with gorgeous artwork, enhanced with animation and visual effects timed with story events. The music is wonderful, with synchronized changes and leitmotif cues.

I'm new to visual novels, and the concept and writing drew me in. Choices are presented frequently and sensibly enough, with a flower appearing in the top-right corner to note when your choice impacted your playthrough outcome. The nonlinearity of the choices provides multiple interesting paths to four basic outcomes with multiple permutations based on your relationships with other characters, as well as your protagonist's personality. Subsequent playthroughs are easy, as dialogue can be skipped (super fast-forward), automatically stopping at new dialogue or choices.

The writing is generally solid and engaging, with very few spots that are slightly clunky but easily forgivable. Character development is deep for the four women, and amusingly and probably intentionally, the supporting cast of men are somewhat one-dimensional. The concept of a reimagined Cinderella itself is quite fun and more contemporary with an emphasis on female protagonist agency, with some very helpful friends to retain the fanciful nature of the original story.

If you're new to visual novels but like things like Joe Dever's Lone Wolf saga, RPGs with deep character development, and Telltale's Walking Dead series, and consider the possibility that games can be art, you would probably enjoy this.

reviewText:
Cinders, a twist on the classic Cinderella fairy tale, is all about its characters. It has all the elements of Cinderella: A ball, a prince you can pursue, evil stepsisters and stepmother, and a fairy godmother. However, Cinders herself is a strong, optimistic, and self-reliant woman capable of taking her future into her own hands. Her stepsisters and stepmother are well developed characters that you can get to know and maybe even understand. The fairy godmother isn't perfect and neither is the prince. Add to that the Captain, the town witch, and Cinder's old friend the merchant, and you have a variety of extremely interesting characters with their own stories and complicated relations to you and each other. Throughout the game, your interactions with them and your decisions for Cinders helps her decide which path to freedom to take. Each broad ending has a variety of unique and lovely sub-types.

If this hasn't told you this game is worth playing, then add to that the lovely artwork with small background animations and very realistic and expressive character art, the beautiful music, and the tiny fact that the dialogue speed matches the speed of the character speaking. This last fact really helps you mentally hear how people are speaking. Honestly, it's as close as you can get to voice acting without actually having voice acting in it.

tl;dr Go play Cinders. It's amazing. 10/10

Your stepmother and stepsisters are more than just villians, they are characters/people with lives and motivations that you can choose to understand/learn about or not. reviewText:
Cinders is a very beautiful game, probably one of the most gorgeous games I have played.  It is not only an amazing visual novel with a dark, mature take on the story of Cinderella, but also contains elements of dating sims and roleplay as well.  I really enjoyed the wide ranges of decisions to make along with the variations of multiple endings.  Not to mention the dialogue is very well written, with very deep philosophical tones and also some comical moments as well - especially with a few fourth wall breakings.  All in all, this is a very good visual novel and certainly won't be disappointing.

Pros:
- Beautiful artwork - every character and background is absolutely gorgeous
- Nice subtle animation - it really helps bring the novel to life and draws more attention
- Amazing soundtrack - I would purchase the soundtrack if they offered it
- Interesting Storyline - has a nice, dark twist to Cinderella while also including elements such as identity, self-empowerment, independence, decisions, and more.  It's not only a story, it's plenty of food for thought as well.
- Variety of Decisions - there are so many to make and it really helps drive the story in different directions, which makes things all the more interesting.
- Great Character Development - all of the characters have a distinct appearance and personality and it really shows not only visually, but in their dialogue.  It's fascinating to get to know them and it also helps them feel very real.  This part was truly amazing.
- Replay Value - you get different achievements from different decisions and different endings, so there's a nice challenge

Cons:
- The dialogue can get a little repetitive at some points.  There's some parts where a character will emphasize something and then it will be emphasized again and again.  This part makes the subject they're emphasizing a little too drawn out.
- Replay Value can feel tedious if already played through trying to get the achievements.
- Personally, I wish it was longer.

Overall, this is a very charming visual novel with many great qualities in terms of aesthetic artwork, intriguing storyline, and heartfelt character development.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Beautiful game with a lot of player agency but not labeled correctly by the devs and 'flat' romances.

I really liked playing this game and I would warmly recommend it to any VN fans out there. That's not to say it's without faults but it's a very good take on the genre.

Pros:
- The artwork. It's gorgeous, it's original, it's great.
- Player agency. You have choices and they matter (GASP!). You get to see the consequences of some choices soon after making them, other later on but it's so rewarding to have a story that can go in so many different directions.
- Endings. No 'secret' or 'true' ending, your choices can lead to an ending that fully reflects the kind of character you wanted Cinder to be and that ending can be good or bad depending on your actions.
- The NPCs. They are more than one-trick ponies whose one-sided personality is the end-all be-all of whom they are.
- Info. The information you get from certain actions can be used later on, if you choose, leading to a lot of branching in how you play.

Cons:
- The labels. It's NOT an RPG. Labeling it as such is misleading to people who are looking for RPGs in the store. It's a visual novel, do not be fooled. (Yes, you take on the 'role' of Cinder but then EVERY game is an RPG and the label loses its meaning, not helping anyone anymore.)
- The romance. If you're gonna add romance options, make them good. There could have been more depth to this aspect of the game as a lot of it was not as fleshed out as I could have wished.
- The variation. With so much variations there's a lot of aspects of the story that are simply introduced and then not really explored, this is a real shame as some of them are really interesting.

In conclusion: I don't have a lot of gripes with this game as I truly enjoyed it. There's a lot of consideration for player input and choices and if you enjoy visual novels, I definitely think you'll like this.

The artwork is gorgeous, both the character designs and particularly the background scenery are very impressive.
